abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated as
            satisfactory. The key lessons to be learned are: 1) Targeted
            poverty interventions of the self-employment type are an
            effective instrument for transferring resources directly to
            the poor. 2) Decentralized financial management at the
            community level is central to successful implementation of
            bottom-up approaches to development and for promoting a
            culture of financial discipline in managing community funds.
            3) Demonstrated ownership and empowerment are key to
            effective participation of farmers in small rural
            development operations. 4) Training in farm management
            skills promotes financial sustainability, while simplified
            operating procedures, legal protection and clarity with
            respect to benefits of the established financial mechanisms
            are central to establishing ownership and credibility of
            such mechanisms. 5) Access of farmers to project and/or
            extension staff is central to effective problem-solving at
            the community levels. 6) Continuity of project
            implementation staff and Bank staff ensures reliability and
            better quality of services to the project. 7) Public
            administration is generally less effective than a private
            association of the beneficiaries. 8) It is risky to make
            long-term investments in community-based agricultural
            enterprises without resolving tradition-bound land tenure
            constraints and disputes. 9) Operations designed to develop
            local capacity and a participatory culture require long-term commitment.
